description: Kyllo v. United States - thermal imaging of home
facts: Agents used thermal imaging device on Kyllo's home from public street
Device detected heat patterns suggesting marijuana growing operation
Technology not in general public use
Heat signatures revealed details of home interior
asp_facts: case(kyllo). amendment(kyllo, fourth). surveillance_type(kyllo, thermal_imaging). target(kyllo, home). warrant_obtained(kyllo, no). technology_in_public_use(kyllo, no). interior_details_revealed(kyllo, yes). physical_intrusion(kyllo, no). observation_from_public_area(kyllo, yes).
question: Does use of thermal imaging device to detect heat emanating from home constitute a Fourth Amendment search?
rationale: Using sense-enhancing technology not in general public use to explore details of a home that would previously have been unknowable without physical intrusion constitutes a Fourth Amendment search. The home receives maximum Fourth Amendment protection, requiring a warrant for such technological surveillance.
